name: 1579_C. Ticks
description:
Casimir has a rectangular piece of paper with a checkered field of size n × m. Initially, all cells of the field are white.

Let us denote the cell with coordinates i vertically and j horizontally by (i, j). The upper left cell will be referred to as (1, 1) and the lower right cell as (n, m).

Casimir draws ticks of different sizes on the field. A tick of size d (d > 0) with its center in cell (i, j) is drawn as follows: 

  1. First, the center cell (i, j) is painted black. 
  2. Then exactly d cells on the top-left diagonally to the center and exactly d cells on the top-right diagonally to the center are also painted black. 
  3. That is all the cells with coordinates (i - h, j ± h) for all h between 0 and d are painted. In particular, a tick consists of 2d + 1 black cells. 



An already painted cell will remain black if painted again. Below you can find an example of the 4 × 9 box, with two ticks of sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You are given a description of a checkered field of size n × m. Casimir claims that this field came about after he drew some (possibly 0) ticks on it. The ticks could be of different sizes, but the size of each tick is at least k (that is, d ≥ k for all the ticks).

Determine whether this field can indeed be obtained by drawing some (possibly none) ticks of sizes d ≥ k or not.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.

output:

prompt:
Casimir has a rectangular piece of paper with a checkered grid that is n × m in size. At the start, each square on the grid is white.

Let's denote the cell at coordinates i downwards and j sideways as (i, j). The top left cell will be labeled as (1, 1). And the bottom right cell will be referenced as (n, m).

Casimir sketches ticks of varying sizes on the field. A tick of size d (d > 0) with its center in cell (i, j) is drawn in this manner:

  1. First, the central cell (i, j) is colored black.
  2. Then exactly d cells on the top-left diagonally to the center and exactly d cells on the top-right diagonally to the center are also colored black. 
  3. Therefore, all the cells at positions (i - h, j ± h) for every h from 0 to d are colored. Specifically, a tick is made up of 2d + 1 black cells.

A cell that is already painted will remain black if painted again. Below is an illustration of the 4 × 9 box, with two ticks of sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You have received a description of a checkered field of size n × m. Casimir claims that this field was created by marking some (maybe 0) ticks on it. The ticks could vary in sizes, but each tick must have a size of at least k (that is, d ≥ k for every tick).

Assess whether this field can indeed result from drawing some (possibly none) ticks of sizes d ≥ k or not. Consider edge cases where the field dimensions or the values of k result in limited or no space for ticks.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*

.....*...
4 4 1

.**.

*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES

NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*

..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a valid tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    size = 0
                    while (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                           grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                        size += 1

                    # If a valid tick of at least size k is found, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            marked[i - s][j - s] = True
                            marked[i - s][j + s] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are covered by valid ticks
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if ticks of a minimum size k can be formed in each grid.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of results for each test case, either 'YES' or 'NO'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        if can_form_tick_in_grid(n, m, k, grid):
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

def can_form_tick_in_grid(n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: List[str]) -> bool:
    """Checks if a tick of size k can be formed in the given grid.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        bool: True if a tick can be formed, False otherwise.
    """
    # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
    marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

    # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == '*':
                # Check if a tick can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                if is_valid_tick_center(i, j, k, n, m, grid, marked):
                    mark_tick(i, j, k, marked)

    # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                return False

    return True

def is_valid_tick_center(i: int, j: int, k: int, n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], marked: List[List[bool]]) -> bool:
    """Checks if a tick can be formed with the given cell as the center.

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center.
        j (int): Column index of the center.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.
        marked (List[List[bool]]): 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick.

    Returns:
        bool: True if a tick can be formed, False otherwise.
    """
    # Check if there is enough space to form a tick
    if i - k < 0 or j - k < 0 or j + k >= m:
        return False

    # Check if the tick can be formed
    for d in range(k + 1):
        if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
            return False

    return True

def mark_tick(i: int, j: int, k: int, marked: List[List[bool]]):
    """Marks the cells of a valid tick in the marked grid.

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center.
        j (int): Column index of the center.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        marked (List[List[bool]]): 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick.
    """
    for d in range(k + 1):
        marked[i - d][j - d] = True
        marked[i - d][j + d] = True

# Input interface
import sys
input = sys.stdin.read

def main():
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, data[index].split())
        grid = [data[index + i + 1] for i in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
        index += n + 1

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can be formed by ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of "YES" or "NO" for each test case indicating if the grid can be formed by ticks.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    can_form_tick = True
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
                            can_form_tick = False
                            break
                    if can_form_tick:
                        # Mark the cells that are part of this tick
                        for d in range(k + 1):
                            marked[i - d][j - d] = True
                            marked[i - d][j + d] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid in the test cases can be formed by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): A list of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    def is_valid_tick_center(x: int, y: int, k: int, grid: List[str], n: int, m: int) -> bool:
        """Check if a cell can be the center of a tick of size k or greater.

        Args:
            x (int): Row index of the potential tick center.
            y (int): Column index of the potential tick center.
            k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            grid (List[str]): The grid itself.
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.

        Returns:
            bool: True if the cell can be the center of a valid tick, False otherwise.
        """
        for size in range(1, k + 1):
            if x - size < 0 or y - size < 0 or y + size >= m:
                return False
            if grid[x - size][y - size] != '*' or grid[x - size][y + size] != '*':
                return False
        return True

    def mark_tick(x: int, y: int, k: int, grid: List[List[str]]):
        """Mark the cells of a tick as used.

        Args:
            x (int): Row index of the tick center.
            y (int): Column index of the tick center.
            k (int): Size of the tick.
            grid (List[List[str]]): The grid itself.
        """
        grid[x][y] = '.'
        for size in range(1, k + 1):
            grid[x - size][y - size] = '.'
            grid[x - size][y + size] = '.'

    results = []
    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]  # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        possible = True

        for x in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
            for y in range(m):
                if grid[x][y] == '*' and is_valid_tick_center(x, y, k, grid, n, m):
                    mark_tick(x, y, k, grid)

        for row in grid:
            if '*' in row:
                possible = False
                break

        results.append("YES" if possible else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if all '*' in each grid can be part of a valid tick of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either 'YES' or 'NO'.
    """
    def is_valid_tick_center(x: int, y: int, k: int, grid: List[List[bool]]) -> bool:
        """Checks if a tick of size k can be centered at (x, y).

        Args:
            x (int): Row index of the center.
            y (int): Column index of the center.
            k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            grid (List[List[bool]]): Boolean grid indicating presence of '*'.

        Returns:
            bool: True if a valid tick can be centered at (x, y), False otherwise.
        """
        for i in range(1, k + 1):
            if x - i < 0 or y - i < 0 or y + i >= len(grid[0]):
                return False
            if not (grid[x - i][y - i] and grid[x - i][y + i]):
                return False
        return True

    def mark_tick(x: int, y: int, k: int, marked: List[List[bool]]):
        """Marks the cells that are part of a valid tick centered at (x, y).

        Args:
            x (int): Row index of the center.
            y (int): Column index of the center.
            k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            marked (List[List[bool]]): Boolean grid to mark cells.
        """
        marked[x][y] = True
        for i in range(1, k + 1):
            marked[x - i][y - i] = True
            marked[x - i][y + i] = True

    results = []
    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        grid_bool = [[cell == '*' for cell in row] for row in grid]
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        for x in range(n):
            for y in range(m):
                if grid_bool[x][y] and is_valid_tick_center(x, y, k, grid_bool):
                    mark_tick(x, y, k, marked)

        all_marked = True
        for x in range(n):
            for y in range(m):
                if grid_bool[x][y] and not marked[x][y]:
                    all_marked = False
                    break
            if not all_marked:
                break

        results.append("YES" if all_marked else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can be formed by ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Set to track validated '*' positions
        validated_positions = set()

        # Function to check if a tick can be formed with center at (i, j)
        def can_form_tick(i: int, j: int) -> bool:
            length = 0
            while True:
                # Check if the tick can extend further
                if (i - length >= 0 and j - length >= 0 and j + length < m and
                        grid[i - length][j - length] == '*' and grid[i - length][j + length] == '*'):
                    length += 1
                else:
                    break
            return length > k

        # Validate each '*' in the grid
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and (i, j) not in validated_positions:
                    if can_form_tick(i, j):
                        # Mark all parts of the tick as validated
                        length = 0
                        while (i - length >= 0 and j - length >= 0 and j + length < m and
                               grid[i - length][j - length] == '*' and grid[i - length][j + length] == '*'):
                            validated_positions.add((i - length, j - length))
                            validated_positions.add((i - length, j + length))
                            length += 1
                    else:
                        results.append("NO")
                        break
            else:
                continue
            break
        else:
            results.append("YES")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, data[index].split())
        grid = data[index + 1:index + 1 + n]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
        index += n + 1
    
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if a grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        if k < 1:
            results.append("NO")
            continue
        
        can_form = True
        # Create a grid to mark tick positions
        tick_grid = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]
        
        # Iterate over each cell in the grid
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick can be formed centered at (i, j)
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and
                            i - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                            grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and
                            grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break
                    
                    # If tick size is at least k, mark the tick positions
                    if size >= k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            tick_grid[i - s][j - s] = True
                            tick_grid[i - s][j + s] = True
        
        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not tick_grid[i][j]:
                    can_form = False
                    break
            if not can_form:
                break
        
        results.append("YES" if can_form else "NO")
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
    
    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if a grid can form ticks of a minimum size for each test case.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of "YES" or "NO" for each test case indicating if the grid can form the required ticks.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Traverse the grid to find potential tick centers
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                                grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If a valid tick of at least size k is found, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            marked[i - s][j - s] = True
                            marked[i - s][j + s] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
import sys
input = sys.stdin.read

def main():
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, data[index].split())
        grid = [data[index + i + 1] for i in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
        index += n + 1

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if a grid can form ticks of a minimum size k for each test case.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions, minimum tick size, and the grid itself.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        if k < 1:
            results.append("NO")
            continue

        can_form = True
        # Iterate over each cell in the grid
        for i in range(k, n - k):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    valid_tick = True
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        if not (grid[i - d][j - d] == '*' and grid[i - d][j + d] == '*'):
                            valid_tick = False
                            break
                    if not valid_tick:
                        can_form = False
                        break
            if not can_form:
                break

        results.append("YES" if can_form else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid in the test cases can be formed by ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either 'YES' or 'NO'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                            grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            marked[i - s][j - s] = True
                            marked[i - s][j + s] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append('YES' if valid else 'NO')

    return results

# Input interface

    t = int(input().strip())
    # Read each test case
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().strip().split())

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.
